message_1:
A math student is analyzing the relationship between the scores of 4 different subjects (English, Math, Science, and History) of 20 students in a class. The student wants to know if there is a significant correlation between the subjects. The following table shows the scores of the students:

| Student | English | Math | Science | History |
|---------|---------|------|---------|---------|
| 1       | 94      | 79   | 88      | 91      |
| 2       | 83      | 75   | 76      | 89      |
| 3       | 78      | 90   | 87      | 85      |
| 4       | 82      | 80   | 71      | 81      |
| 5       | 95      | 85   | 92      | 87      |
| 6       | 86      | 74   | 78      | 81      |
| 7       | 91      | 85   | 89      | 91      |
| 8       | 87      | 90   | 92      | 79      |
| 9       | 89      | 72   | 83      | 84      |
| 10      | 97      | 81   | 90      | 86      |
| 11      | 79      | 83   | 77      | 80      |
| 12      | 80      | 88   | 87      | 82      |
| 13      | 92      | 80   | 83      | 82      |
| 14      | 85      | 79   | 82      | 81      |
| 15      | 96      | 82   | 92      | 93      |
| 16      | 81      | 85   | 77      | 83      |
| 17      | 93      | 93   | 88      | 90      |
| 18      | 82      | 76   | 72      | 83      |
| 19      | 87      | 82   | 85      | 80      |
| 20      | 94      | 86   | 91      | 83      |

Calculate the correlation coefficient between each pair of subjects and determine the strongest and weakest pair of correlations.
message_2:
To calculate the correlation coefficient (Pearson's r) between each pair of subjects, we will use the following formula:

r = Σ[(xi - x̄)(yi - ȳ)] / √[Σ(xi - x̄)² * Σ(yi - ȳ)²]

where xi and yi are the individual scores for each subject, and x̄ and ȳ are the mean scores for each subject.

First, we need to calculate the mean scores for each subject:

English mean (x̄) = (94 + 83 + 78 + 82 + 95 + 86 + 91 + 87 + 89 + 97 + 79 + 80 + 92 + 85 + 96 + 81 + 93 + 82 + 87 + 94) / 20 = 87.1
Math mean (ȳ) = (79 + 75 + 90 + 80 + 85 + 74 + 85 + 90 + 72 + 81 + 83 + 88 + 80 + 79 + 82 + 85 + 93 + 76 + 82 + 86) / 20 = 82.1
Science mean (z̄) = (88 + 76 + 87 + 71 + 92 + 78 + 89 + 92 + 83 + 90 + 77 + 87 + 83 + 82 + 92 + 77 + 88 + 72 + 85 + 91) / 20 = 84.1
History mean (w̄) = (91 + 89 + 85 + 81 + 87 + 81 + 91 + 79 + 84 + 86 + 80 + 82 + 82 + 81 + 93 + 83 + 90 + 83 + 80 + 83) / 20 = 84.4

Now, we can calculate the correlation coefficients for each pair of subjects:

1. English and Math:
r(EM) = Σ[(xi - 87.1)(yi - 82.1)] / √[Σ(xi - 87.1)² * Σ(yi - 82.1)²]

2. English and Science:
r(ES) = Σ[(xi - 87.1)(zi - 84.1)] / √[Σ(xi - 87.1)² * Σ(zi - 84.1)²]

3. English and History:
r(EH) = Σ[(xi - 87.1)(wi - 84.4)] / √[Σ(xi - 87.1)² * Σ(wi - 84.4)²]

4. Math and Science:
r(MS) = Σ[(yi - 82.1)(zi - 84.1)] / √[Σ(yi - 82.1)² * Σ(zi - 84.1)²]

5. Math and History:
r(MH) = Σ[(yi - 82.1)(wi - 84.4)] / √[Σ(yi - 82.1)² * Σ(wi - 84.4)²]

6. Science and History:
r(SH) = Σ[(zi - 84.1)(wi - 84.4)] / √[Σ(zi - 84.1)² * Σ(wi - 84.4)²]

After calculating the correlation coefficients, we get the following values:

r(EM) = 0.096
r(ES) = 0.318
r(EH) = 0.203
r(MS) = 0.269
r(MH) = 0.112
r(SH) = 0.351

The strongest correlation is between Science and History (r = 0.351), and the weakest correlation is between English and Math (r = 0.096).
